div.p: The redesign of our services or our taxes is probably a big challenge to us that needs
to be understood by everybody who’s listening to this. You know, we have digitalised before
just existing practices and therefore it brings challenge. If you take self-assessment for
example, a great online service, but you can’t pay online. You just took the old practices
and actually digitalised them.
What we need to do now and what we are doing is business process re-engineering, taking
every single process we have, every core tax, and re-designing it completely in an end-to-end
way, and then digitalising it. That sounds so obvious and rudimentary now if you think
about, but in fact for us that’s a major breakthrough. Taking a tax, no matter where
it sits in the organisation, no matter what the hierarchy or the departmental siloes are
that manage it, redesigning it and then digitalising it.
HMRC over the years has suffered from something other parts of government have suffered with
before. That is, we try to invent everything for ourselves. We haven’t looked at the
market to do stuff; we’ve done it for ourselves. One of the biggest challenges we’ve found
when we did self-assessment online is that people needed some payroll mechanism to record
and provide data to us and employers needed the same. Therefore, we began to give away
free software. That is very simple, very generic software, it enabled them to do things with
us in the PAYE space.
The biggest challenge of course, actually the market said, “We could do better. We
could actually add it into other features, we could sell it as part of a service.”
But of course HMRC said, “No, no. It’s us. We’re HMRC. It’s kind of unique stuff.”
But of course, we began increasingly to realise we couldn’t keep up with the market. We
couldn’t featurise it, we couldn’t make it very rich. The market began demand of us
access to those core mechanisms or APIs, the core infrastructure that goes behind the coding
of those payroll solutions. So we began to give it away.
We found the payroll industry took it way beyond anything we could ever have done. It’s
built a strong relationship between us and the payroll market, so much so, things like
real-time, the actual modernisation of PAYE, is being done through these payroll providers.
And because we have had such a strong relationship, it’s been a very powerful joint approach
to the new way to do PAYE.
We are eight or nine years into this journey, and of course I’m describing the end result
to you, which sounds great. But looking back, it didn’t need to be this long and didn’t
need to be this painful. I would encourage anybody thinking about this or designing like
this, I think you should start with a default; you’ll give it away, and then decide you’re
not going to, rather than the other way around.
Secondly, it’s the culture of the organisation. Giving anything away in government is always
seen as a problem or needs to be checked, or committees and lawyers and all sorts need
to have their penny’s worth in that. But if you design it with that in mind, I think
it’s very powerful. Give it away, of course you’ll find the market will enrich it dramatically
and give back to you a much richer experience and perhaps, in our case, a better set of
data that’s of a higher quality.
